author: GeneSmith
title: How to have Polygenically Screened Children
summary: Polygenic embryo screening allows prospective parents to select embryos with a reduced risk of certain diseases and higher IQ scores through IVF, offering a potential advantage but at a significant cost ($30,000-$100,000) and with limited, currently achievable improvements.

author: Austin Witte
title: A Brief Overview of AI Safety/Alignment Orgs, Fields, Researchers, and Resources for ML Researchers
summary: Two overview documents, a short and long version, categorize AI safety research by keywords and subject areas to help machine learning researchers quickly assess potential research avenues based on their existing skills. These resources list organizations, researchers, papers, and other materials relevant to the field through the end of 2022.

author: Mark Xu
title: Intermittent Distllations - AI Alignment Forum
summary: This publication intermittently summarizes AI safety-relevant content, reflecting the author's emphasis on careful reading and summarization.

author: Alex Flint
title: Life and expanding steerable consequences
summary: The article categorizes objects based on their "steerable consequences"—whether their effects diminish or expand over time. While a rock's impact is limited and unpredictable, organisms like mold or humans exhibit "expanding steerability," where a small initial action can predictably cause large-scale, long-term effects.

author: Vika, Ramana Kumar
title: Optimization Concepts in the Game of Life
summary: The article defines and applies the concepts of robustness and retargetability (from Flint's work on optimization) to Conway's Game of Life, using it as a simplified model for studying embedded agency. The authors aim to better understand agency in AI systems by analyzing this simple, yet rich, environment.

author: Cullen
title: AI Benefits Post 1: Introducing “AI Benefits”
summary: This article initiates a series exploring how artificial intelligence can benefit humanity beyond typical market-driven applications. The author focuses on AI applications that address societal needs underserved by profit-maximizing businesses, such as global public goods and products benefitting low-income populations.

author: Daniel Kokotajlo
title: Relevant pre-AGI possibilities
summary: This blog post brainstorms plausible future societal changes that could significantly impact the development and safety of advanced artificial general intelligence (AGI), presenting a list of possibilities categorized by their potential relevance to timelines, technical AI safety, and policy. An interactive tool allows users to generate possible future scenarios based on assigned probabilities for each listed change.

title: What are the public health implications of the life course perspective?
abstract: ABSTRACT During the past decades innovative research has shown that exposure to harmful events during pregnancy and early infancy ('the first 1000 days') has an impact on health at subsequent stages of the life course and even across generations. Recently it has been shown that even the pre-conception period is of outmost importance, and other scholars have made the case that the 1000 days should be extended to a period of 8000 days post-conception. The present contribution aims to bridge further the gap between research evidence and public health policy by applying a holistic 'full-cycle' perspective. Thus, a conceptual framework is suggested for guiding public health prioritization, including the variables of 'impact on the next generation', 'plasticity' and 'available interventions with documented impact'. This framework could guide decision makers in selecting at which stages of the life course to invest (and not), and furthermore it points to some pertinent research priorities.
summary: The paper advocates for a "full-cycle" life course perspective in public health, arguing that exposures from preconception through early childhood significantly impact health across generations and proposing a framework to prioritize interventions based on impact, plasticity, and available evidence.
